parts.text:

[Statement 2]: Two other studies found there were fewer aphids in plots with cover crops between broccoli plants compared to plots without cover crops.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found that growing cover crops in winter can lead to less severely diseased lettuces.
[Statement 4]: When cover crops are grown in winter, less water was lost through drainage, runoff or evaporation.
[Statement 5]: Growing cover crops in winter can lead to lower cash crop yields.
[Statement 6]: Four studies found that less nitrate was leached from soils with winter cover crops compared to soils without winter cover crops.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies in India and Pakistan on clay loam soil found that growing green manures led to higher soil organic carbon.
[Statement 2]: Two controlled, randomized, replicated studies in India and Pakistan on clay loam soil found that growing green manures led to increased grain yields.
[Statement 3]: For cover crops, one meta-analysis and ten replicated, controlled studies found more organic matter in soils with winter cover crops compared to soils without winter cover crops.
[Statement 4]: One replicated study and one review found increased soil carbon levels under cover crops.
[Statement 5]: One replicated study and one review found a further increase in soil carbon when legumes were included with cover crops.
[Statement 6]: Another study reported more carbon accumulation in soils with cover crops.
[Statement 7]: The effect of cover crops on crop yield is varied.
[Statement 8]: Six studies found lower cash crop yields in plots with winter cover crops.
[Statement 9]: Three studies found higher cash crop yields in plots with winter cover crops.
[Statement 10]: Eight studies showed inconsistent differences in cash crop yields between plots with or without cover crops.
[Statement 11]: Seven studies found no differences in cash crop yields between plots with or without cover crops.
[Statement 12]: Eight studies found higher cash crop yields when legumes were used as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes.
[Statement 13]: One study found higher tomato yield from soils that had a ryegrass cover crop.

[Statement 1]: Studies in Europe and other regions on sandy loam and other soil types have examined the effects of different tillage practices.
[Statement 2]: Identified benefits of reduced tillage include an increase in microbes, earthworm species, and microbe activity.
[Statement 3]: Reduced tillage has been found to decrease soil compaction in some studies.
[Statement 4]: A decrease in soil compaction from reduced tillage can lead to reduced water runoff.
[Statement 5]: Reduced tillage has been shown to lower soil loss and runoff compared to conventional ploughing.
[Statement 6]: Twelve studies noted higher soil organic carbon under no-tillage or reduced tillage systems.
[Statement 7]: Eight studies observed that no-tillage or reduced tillage systems maintained or increased soil organic matter.
[Statement 8]: Eight studies observed that no-tillage or reduced tillage systems improved soil structure.
[Statement 9]: Drawbacks and mixed results for reduced tillage were also reported.
[Statement 10]: Three replicated trials found higher soil compaction under reduced tillage.
[Statement 11]: Two trials showed that no-tillage increased soil loss when there was no crop cover.
[Statement 12]: Some studies found that reduced tillage had mixed effects on microbe diversity.
[Statement 13]: Some studies found reduced tillage had no effect on earthworm or microbe activity.
[Statement 14]: Some studies found reduced tillage had mixed effects on soil nitrogen levels.
[Statement 15]: One trial in Spain found greater soil organic carbon in conventionally tilled soil.
[Statement 16]: One Canadian study found lower crop yields under minimum or no-tillage.
[Statement 17]: A Portuguese study found no effect on crop yield from the tillage treatment.
[Statement 18]: Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling were found in three trials to increase the soil's ability to absorb water.
[Statement 19]: Conventional ploughing and sub-soiling were found in three trials to increase the soil's water content.
[Statement 20]: Related practices on sandy loam soils include the use of cover crops and mulch.
[Statement 21]: Cover crops have been found to increase bacterial numbers and activity.
[Statement 22]: Cover crops have been found to reduce erosion.
[Statement 23]: Adding mulch has been shown in European studies to increase soil animal and fungal numbers, diversity, and activity.
[Statement 24]: Adding mulch has been shown to reduce soil erosion and runoff.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence regarding the impact of cover crops on crop yields in the USA shows varied results.
[Statement 2]: Some replicated, controlled studies in Spain and the USA found lower cash crop yields in certain instances with winter cover crops.
[Statement 3]: Some replicated, controlled studies in Italy and the USA found higher cash crop yields with winter cover crops.
[Statement 4]: Some studies in Italy and the USA reported inconsistent differences in cash crop yields between plots with and without cover crops.
[Statement 5]: Some controlled studies in France, Israel, Spain, and the USA found no differences in cash crop yields between plots with and without cover crops.
[Statement 6]: A US study found inconsistent yield differences with summer cover crops.
[Statement 7]: The type of cover crop used appears to be a significant factor.
[Statement 8]: Some studies in Italy and the USA found higher cash crop yields when legumes were used as winter cover crops compared to non-legumes.
[Statement 9]: A US study found higher yields with a mixture of legumes and grasses compared to legumes alone.
[Statement 10]: A replicated study in the USA found that tillage can have mixed effects on soil erosion when crop residues are removed.
[Statement 11]: The studies that found higher crop yields when retaining residues were conducted in Australia and China, not the USA.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has led to increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 2]: Amending the soil with fresh plant material or crop remains has led to improved soil structure.

[Statement 8]: Retaining crop residues has been associated with decreased water runoff, increased water storage, and reduced soil erosion.
[Statement 9]: Retaining crop residues has been shown to increase soil organic carbon and nitrogen levels.
[Statement 10]: Retaining crop residues has been shown to lead to higher yields.
[Statement 11]: Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals can reduce weed growth.

[Statement 13]: Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown mixed results on crop growth and yield.
[Statement 14]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can result in higher microbial biomass and activity.
[Statement 15]: Using a mix of organic and inorganic amendments can result in more organic carbon in the soil.

[Statement 17]: A mixture of organic and inorganic amendments was found to increase maize yield.

[Statement 4]: One trial on the application of nitrification inhibitors found no effect on nitrate loss.

[Statement 6]: One trial found reduced soil loss when aluminium sulphate was applied to the soil.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A replicated study in Mexico indicated that retaining crop residues increased microbial biomass.
[Statement 2]: A review noted that retaining crop residues reduced water runoff and soil erosion.

[Statement 9]: A randomized, replicated experiment in Belgium found that amending soil with fresh plant material or crop remains increased microbial biomass.

[Statement 11]: A before-and-after trial in the UK found that incorporating straw did not improve compacted, anaerobic soils.
[Statement 12]: One randomized, replicated study from Canada and India found that straw addition reduced soil loss.
[Statement 13]: Another study on straw addition reported mixed effects on soil loss, depending on the soil type.
[Statement 14]: Four replicated studies from the UK, USA, and Belgium reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied.
[Statement 15]: The results for soil nitrogen levels were mixed when processed wastes were added to the soil.
[Statement 16]: Six studies in China, Denmark, and India all found higher carbon levels when plant material was added to the soil.
[Statement 17]: Incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals has shown varied results.
[Statement 18]: Three out of six studies found that incorporating plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals caused a reduction in weed growth.
[Statement 19]: Two of three studies found that crop growth was inhibited by plant remains that produce weed-controlling chemicals.
[Statement 20]: The inhibition of crop growth by plant remains could be minimized by changing the application timing.
[Statement 21]: The effects of incorporating plant remains on crop yield were inconsistent, with studies finding positive, negative, and mixed results.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In the USA, the use of different agricultural practices has shown varied effects on crop yields.
[Statement 2]: Some studies found that growing winter cover crops in arable fields led to lower cash crop yields.
[Statement 3]: Other studies reported that growing winter cover crops in arable fields led to higher or inconsistent cash crop yields.
[Statement 4]: One study found inconsistent differences in cash crop yields with summer cover crops.
[Statement 5]: Some studies in the USA found differences in tomato quality with winter cover crops.
[Statement 6]: Another study in the USA found inconsistent differences in cash crop quality with winter cover crops.
[Statement 7]: The use of legumes as winter cover crops was found to result in higher cash crop yields compared to non-legumes.
[Statement 8]: In US orchards and vineyards, some studies found that seeding grass between vine rows lowered grape yields.
[Statement 9]: Other studies in US orchards and vineyards found similar grape yields when seeding grass between vine rows.
[Statement 10]: One study in the USA found that forgoing tillage between vine rows could result in higher grape yields and heavier clusters in some cases.
[Statement 11]: Adding compost to the soil in the USA has led to higher, inconsistent, or similar crop yields in different studies.
[Statement 12]: One US study found that adding fertilizer to compost did not lead to a difference in crop yields.

[Statement 1]: Reducing fertilizer, pesticide, or herbicide use can increase the diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms.
[Statement 2]: Controlling farm traffic might have an impact on soil biodiversity.
[Statement 3]: A study in Poland indicated that controlled traffic resulted in higher numbers and bacterial activity.
[Statement 4]: A study in Denmark found that microbial biomass was higher when farm traffic was not controlled.
[Statement 5]: Converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the number of soil organisms.
[Statement 6]: Converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the diversity of soil organisms.
[Statement 7]: Converting to organic farming has been shown to increase the activity of soil organisms.
